results.title: Wings over the navy
results.brief_description: This is the story of the Australian Naval Aviation - of the carrier HMAS Sydney - and of he intricate and intensive training given to the men who men her and the pilots who fly her aircraft.

results.title: Wings for tomorrow
results.brief_description: The importance of models in aviation is depicted, showing that although they give enjoyment to the enthusiasts who make and fly them, they also give very valuable training to designers, technicians, and flyers, both present and future. It shows how the crew members of today get their early graining, in many instances, flying models of yesterday. Various models from gliders to jets are shown, both on the ground, and in the air.

results.title: Wings across the world
results.creator_credit: Anthony de Lotbinière, Norman Swallow and BBC
results.brief_description: An account of world-wide commercial aviation showing how it operates and is controlled. The aim of the International Civil Aviation Organization is to establish and maintain standards of safety and comfort. Film includes sequences shot in Bolivia, Afghanistan, Beirut, Montreal and Switzerland, along the new routes of the North Pole, at London Airport and in Venezuela. The impact of air travel on primitive peoples, in particular on an Abyssinian peasant who had never seen a railway or a real road.

results.title: Winged world
results.creator_credit: Leo Seltzer and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: Deals with the work of the International Civil Aviation organization whose function is to assist civil aviation in many countries by encouraging the use of safety measures, uniform regulation and simper procedures at national frontiers.

results.title: Winemakers in France
results.brief_description: Describes the winemaking process from pruning the vines to the actual bottling of the wins. Explains how the traditional methods have been replaced by modern mass production methods.

results.title: Winds and their causes
results.brief_description: The crash on a model aeroplane serves as an introduction to the study of winds and their causes; thermals, cumulus clouds, thunderstorms, on and off-shore breezes, easterlies and westerlies are explained in the simplest of terms.

results.title: Window on the world
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Shows the manufacture of Australian louvre windows in a Queensland factory. High grade steel is pressed and cut to form the side brackets; clips to hold the glass are stamped, formed and fitted onto bronze bearing completing a simple, rust and weather-proof frame which locks automatically when closed. The installation of louvre windows is shown. Although many louvres are exported to overseas, the home market uses an ever-increasing number of these windows which are ideally suited to Australian conditions.

results.title: Window on Canada. No. 29
results.brief_description: Host Clyde Gilmour introduces pioneer filmmaker Norman McLaren and presents three of his works. McLaren demonstrates and explains the different animation techniques used in each. Seen are: La-Haut sur ces montagnes and C’est l’aviron from the series Les Chants Populaires, and the upbeat short Boogie Doodle. The film ends with a discussion of McLaren’s work in India and China while on loan to UNESCO from 1949 to 1950. We see two short educational films made by his students in China, using techniques McLaren has taught them.

results.title: Wind: the power and the promise
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Alan P. Sloan and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The devastating power of tornadoes and hurricanes and the various modern techniques which have been developed to harness the power of the winds as an energy source are shown.
